yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní “Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?”; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?
gold: A person says he has lost an unspecified amount of money, and you ask if the amount is five hundred cowries or eleven hundred cowries; which amount did you steal?
gen:
The Yoruba proverb "Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní “Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?”; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?" can be translated to English as: "The pig owner is going to the pig market, and you ask, 'Is it three hundred pigs or six hundred pigs?' Which one do you have there?"

This proverb is used to highlight the absurdity or irrelevance of asking unnecessary questions when the answer is either obvious or irrelevant to the situation. It suggests that one should focus on what is present or available rather than speculating or asking about things that are not pertinent. In essence, it advises against overthinking or complicating matters with unnecessary inquiries.
